quizzes.question:
Fill in the blanks to create a file named "records.txt".
[!raw!]
f = File.{0}("{1}.txt", "w+")
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Creating Files[/h1]

Until now we have been performing input and output tasks using the [b]gets [/b]and [b]puts [/b]methods. A more permanent form of input and output is files.
Ruby allows us to easily create and work with files by using the built-in [b]File [/b]class. [code format="rb" ]file = [b]File[/b].new("test.txt", "w+")[/code]
The code above creates a file named "test.txt" with the mode w+ for read and write access to the file. 
Note that the file will be created in the same directory as our program.
Now we can use our file object to perform different operations. After using a file, it must be closed using the [b]close [/b]method:[code format="rb" ]file.[b]close[/b][/code]
[note]It is necessary to close open files so they no longer continue to occupy space in memory.[/note]

quizzes.question: Fill in the correct mode to create a new file with read-only permission.
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]File Modes[/h1]

Ruby supports the following file modes:
[b]r[/b] read-only, starts at beginning of file (default mode).
[b]r+[/b] read-write, starts at beginning of file.
[b]w[/b] write-only, truncates existing file to zero length or creates a new file for writing.
[b]w+[/b] read-write, truncates existing file to zero length overwriting existing data or creates a new file for reading and writing.
[b]a[/b] write-only, appends to end of file if file exists, otherwise creates a new file for writing.
[b]a+[/b] read-write, appends or reads from end of file if file exists, otherwise creates a new file for reading and writing.
[note]When the open mode is read only, the mode cannot be changed to writable. Similarly, the open mode cannot be changed from write only to readable.[/note]

quizzes.question:
Fill in the blanks to open a file named "db.csv" for write-only access.
[!raw!]
f = {0}.{1}("db.csv", "{2}")
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Opening Files[/h1]

To open an existing file you use the File class  [b]open [/b]method:[code format="rb" ]file = File.[b]open[/b]("filename", "w+") [/code]
[note]As with the [b]new [/b]method, the second argument of the [b]open [/b]method specifies the mode.[/note]
